At 22:03 11/10/2004, you wrote:


>Colin, one problem with your meta-search for the right mutation
>parameters is that it is likely if you find anything at all it will be
>domain-specific.  The fitness landscape ruggedness, hilliness,
>deceptiveness, etc., in different domains is likely to be different.
>
>Therefore, it actually kind of makes sense if you want to search for
>mutation parameters to tie them to the individual genes, since at
>least then the search is domain-specific.  Of course, as you point
>out, this kind of gene-by-gene searching may go all over the place,
>but then again, at least in the ES community (as Ian pointed out),
>they have had some success with this, and it's (I think) almost a
>standard part of their methodology now.

Not only domain-specific, but it is inside each search, rather than an 
externally determined "ideal" value.  E.g. as I mentioned in my previous 
mail...

>There actually is a third, more sophisticated method for getting
>weight mutation parameters, which is to measure the success of
>mutations in various directions in the multidimensional space and
>actually construct a model of the most promising mutation trajectory
>based on the experience over past generations (as a multi-dimensional
>probability distribution).  That has recently popped up in ES as well,
>though the math behind it is not simple at all.

But that is a step away from the basis of an evolutionary search and 
towards a gradient-based method.  Gradient-based methods are 
well-established and the choice for many problems, but they have certain 
weaknesses which evolutionary methods address... IMHO, that is.

>The problem of getting weight mutation right is a little bit of an art
>form and may have an element of alchemy (i.e. there's perhaps not that
>much you can really do without just getting lucky) but then again
>there probably are some ranges that are more reasonable than others
>over multiple domains, so it's not bad to learn more about it.

What you say is true.  But what do people think of the idea than an "ideal" 
evolutionary methodology would not require any user configuration?

         Ian
